p: Levan polysaccharide is a product from the fermentation process of Bacillus subtilis and it has been reported that levan can mediate the activation of TLR4 pathway and results in an increase of the inflammation process [ 89]. A study on B. subtilis isolated from honey showed that the biological activity of levan (Î²-2,6-fructan) produced by these bacteria have antiviral activity against the pathogenic respiratory RNA virus avian influenza (HPAI) A (H5N1) and the enteric DNA adenovirus type 40 [ 30]. Both H5N1 and SARS-CoV are RNA viruses that cause severe viral pneumonia leading to ARDS [ 90] and both viruses have the potential to cause global pandemics [ 91]. Thus, it is crucial to continuously explore potential therapeutics against these viruses, and levan might be a promising compound in honey. Therefore, it would be interesting to evaluate the potential of TLR4-mediated effects from levan in honey to balance the pro-inflammatory versus antiviral effect in patients infected by SARS-CoV2. Moreover, a study using the fish model suggested that levan can facilitate the aggregation of cells and viruses, and thus enhances the phagocytosis process [ 92], but this approach may still require further investigation.
